content: Take responsibility for your learning and shape your experience. Make it what you want it to be.
The more you ask, the more you will learn. No one knows everything.
Results show that those who attend classes get better marks than those who do not. This goes for remote classes too!
They can help with any problems. You might not need them right away, but you might need them later.

metadata.title: 4. Keep in touch with your personal tutor

content: Organise your time around lectures, reading, tutorials, the library and Clubs & Societies. Make time for you to dance, swim, walk, sing and relax.
Everyone is new. Speak to classmates, form study groups and try a new sport. Step outside your comfort zone.
It’s given to help you improve your work and your grades. Give feedback, we like to improve too.
Don’t just stick to the lecture notes. Expand your knowledge.
Feed your brain with thinking fuel. Can’t cook? Learn. Whether you’re a night owl, or an early bird, make sure you sleep. While you sleep, your body is working to maintain your health.

metadata.title: 9. Eat, sleep and look after yourself

content: You are living in one of the greatest, most diverse, cities in the world. Explore, discover, and experience the city, it’s all part of being an Imperial student.

For different theories or methodologies: Use a table to record information – it's much easier to look at the information quickly and do a quick comparison. For procedures and processes: Use a flow chart to record the different stages, and the decision-making process that you will need to work through. For summarising different documents or sources: Make a list of the key points and use prose or linear notes to add any of your own commentary. You could then record how these points link up using a 'mind map' or a diagram. For recording how a piece of equipment works: Use an image or diagram to record details of each part. It doesn't matter if you can't draw well, as long as you understand it.

metadata.title: Note-taking advice
key_points: Use tables for comparing theories or methodologies
Use flow charts for procedures and processes
Use lists and mind maps for summarizing documents
Use diagrams for equipment details

quotes.text: You should try and write up your notes as soon as possible after your lectures and seminars. It will reinforce the knowledge you've learnt, and a little bit of work each day will save you time come revision.
quotes.author: Lloyd James, ICU President 2021-22

quotes.text: Make sure you're taking good notes because they're invaluable at revision times. You can use colour or other visual aids to enhance notes - especially if you're a person that finds it hard to learn from these. Shorter note cards can be really effective for some people; but try to produce these early as they take a long time to make during a revision period
quotes.author: Daniel Lo, ICU Deputy President (Education) 2021-22

content: Imperial College primarily uses Blackboard as its Virtual Learning Environment (VLE) for most departments. Blackboard hosts course materials, discussions, tests, and allows assignment submissions. The Business School uses a custom platform called The Hub. Other digital tools used include Microsoft Teams, Zoom, Panopto, and various online resources provided by the Library. The college also employs specialized technologies like learning laboratories, 'responsive mannequins' in medicine, 3D simulation in geosciences, and interactive whiteboards.

metadata.title: Virtual Learning Environments at Imperial
key_points: Blackboard is the primary VLE for most departments
The Business School uses a custom platform called The Hub
Various digital tools and specialized technologies are used across different programs

content: Imperial College offers a wide range of short online courses across various disciplines. These include A-level Mathematics preparation courses, business-related courses (e.g., Accounting Essentials, Finance Essentials), technology courses (e.g., Advanced App Development in Android, TensorFlow 2), public health and medical courses (e.g., Epidemiology for Public Health, Infectious Disease Modelling), and courses related to climate change and renewable energy. These courses cater to different levels, from pre-university preparation to professional development.

metadata.title: Short Online Courses Overview
key_points: Diverse range of courses covering mathematics, business, technology, health, and environmental topics
Courses available for different levels, from pre-university to professional development
Includes both academic preparation and practical skill development courses

content: University life differs from school in several key ways. Grading is different, with a pass mark typically at 40% and first-class honors at 70% or above. There's a heavy emphasis on online learning, using platforms like Blackboard and Microsoft Teams. Students have more responsibility for their own learning, requiring independent study and time management skills. The learning environment is diverse, with various teaching methods including lectures, tutorials, and practical classes. University also offers more flexibility in study hours and locations. The student body is more diverse, with people from many different countries and backgrounds. Living independently may require developing new skills like cooking.

metadata.title: Key Differences in University Life
key_points: Different grading system with lower percentage thresholds for passing and excellence
Greater emphasis on independent learning and online resources
More diverse learning environments and student body

content: Personal Tutors are allocated to students for the duration of their course to offer help and support with academic or personal issues. They follow your progress and help keep you on track. It's beneficial to develop a good relationship with your tutor, meeting at least twice a term and keeping in touch via email. If your department doesn't allocate a tutor, there will be a Senior Tutor or program manager available for support.

metadata.title: Personal Tutors
key_points: Personal Tutors offer academic and personal support
Meet your tutor at least twice a term
Develop a good relationship with your tutor

content: Senior Tutors are academic staff members responsible for the pastoral care of students in a department. They support Personal Tutors and Supervisors and provide additional guidance in complex situations. If you're uncomfortable talking to your Personal Tutor about a problem, you can speak to your Senior Tutor. Each Faculty also has a Faculty Senior Tutor for additional support.

metadata.title: Senior Tutors
key_points: Senior Tutors oversee pastoral care in departments
They provide support in complex situations
Faculty Senior Tutors offer additional guidance

content: Personal Tutors can discuss any aspect of university life, including course matters, financial worries, personal problems, or any concerns. They advise on academic progress, identify strengths and weaknesses, and suggest improvements. They're also the first point of contact for welfare, financial, or pastoral issues and can provide academic references. If they can't help with a specific issue, they'll suggest appropriate resources or contacts.

metadata.title: Role of Personal Tutors
key_points: Discuss any aspect of university life with Personal Tutors
They provide academic advice and support
Personal Tutors can refer to other support services if needed

content: Lectures are a primary learning method at university, where staff explain core subject material to large groups of students. Lecturers use various styles, including presentations, writing on boards, and demonstrations. Many employ interactive teaching methods, such as asking questions or using tools like Mentimeter. Resources like slides or handouts are often provided online through Blackboard, and lectures are recorded on Panopto for later review.

metadata.title: Lectures
key_points: Lectures explain core subject material to large groups
Various teaching styles and interactive methods are used
Resources and recordings are available online

content: Tutorials involve learning in small groups, allowing for detailed exploration of topics and discussions with tutors and peers. They encourage active learning, improve self-expression, and provide hands-on practice. Students are often expected to prepare work in advance or read about lecture topics for discussion. Tutorials work best when everyone contributes, helping develop confidence in public speaking and using discipline-specific language.

metadata.title: Tutorials
key_points: Small group learning for detailed topic exploration
Encourages active participation and discussion
Helps develop public speaking and subject-specific language skills

content: Practicals provide hands-on learning opportunities to apply knowledge from lectures and tutorials. They may be lab-based, computer-based, involve clinical practice, or fieldwork. Staff, including laboratory tutors, demonstrators, and Graduate Teaching Assistants, provide advice on the working environment and practical skills. Students often need to capture results and notes in a lab book, which may be used for writing assessed lab reports.

metadata.title: Practicals
key_points: Hands-on application of knowledge from lectures and tutorials
Various forms including lab work, computer work, and fieldwork
Results and notes often captured in lab books for later assessment

content: Depending on the course, students may participate in fieldwork, problem classes, or placements. Fieldwork allows application of classroom knowledge to real-world situations. Problem classes provide opportunities to work through questions with support from staff or Graduate Teaching Assistants. Placements, such as Year Abroad or Year in Industry, offer experiences outside the college that count towards the degree. The Careers Service provides support for finding and applying for placement opportunities.

metadata.title: Other Teaching Methods
key_points: Fieldwork applies classroom knowledge to real-world situations
Problem classes offer support for working through questions
Placements provide off-campus experiences counting towards the degree

content: Reading lists provide recommended resources for courses and lectures. The library offers print and e-versions of textbooks. When deciding what to read, consider the purpose, author's key points, publication date, and how to approach the material critically. Evaluate texts and determine how much you need to remember.

metadata.title: Reading Lists
key_points: Check library resources before buying textbooks
Consider the purpose and relevance of reading materials
Approach texts critically and evaluate their content

content: Essential study equipment includes pens, notepads, and highlighters for organizing notes. While not mandatory, most students find having a personal computer beneficial for studying and completing assignments. Laptops offer flexibility for working in various locations. Recording lectures requires permission, and some are recorded via Panopto. Printers are available on campus, but consider what truly needs printing to save costs.

metadata.title: Study Equipment and Technology
key_points: Basic stationery is essential for note-taking
Personal computers, especially laptops, are beneficial but not mandatory
Consider campus resources like printers and lecture recordings

content: The transition to university involves new freedoms and responsibilities. Students are expected to develop as independent learners, working autonomously outside of lectures and tutorials. This includes preparing for sessions, engaging actively in learning, and exploring areas of interest beyond the curriculum. Seeking support when needed is a key attribute of an independent student.

metadata.title: Adjusting to University Study
key_points: Develop independence in learning and time management
Engage actively in your studies and explore beyond the curriculum
Seek support when needed - it's a sign of a good student

content: Plan your route to campus, considering walking, cycling, or public transport. Attend course induction activities to understand your course structure and meet tutors and classmates. Identify key contacts for your program, including course organizers and administrators. Participate in events organized by Imperial College Union to experience life outside studies and meet other students.

metadata.title: Your First Week
key_points: Plan your route to campus
Attend course induction activities
Identify key program contacts
Participate in extracurricular events

content: Imperial has multiple campuses in London and the South East. Use online maps and mobile applications to navigate. Be aware of personal safety and follow Transport for London for updates on public transport. Explore the city's attractions, museums, and parks in your free time. Don't worry about getting lost during the day, as it can help you learn the area, but take safety precautions.

metadata.title: Finding Your Way Around Imperial
metadata.main_title: Finding your way around Imperial College London
key_points: Use online maps and apps to navigate multiple campuses
Be aware of personal safety, especially when exploring
Take advantage of London's attractions and public transport

content: Imperial offers over 340 Clubs, Societies & Projects (CSPs) covering academic, arts, charitable, cultural, and sports interests. Joining CSPs helps maintain a work-life balance, continue hobbies or try new activities, and meet people outside your course. CSPs are run by student volunteers, with opportunities to join committees and gain leadership skills. Joining is easy; attend the Welcome Fair or contact CSPs directly throughout the year.

metadata.title: Student Clubs and Societies
key_points: Over 340 diverse CSPs available
Helps maintain work-life balance and meet new people
Opportunities for leadership and skill development

content: Studying at Imperial makes you part of a diverse community of students, staff, and alumni. Engage in various activities to enhance your experience, such as joining clubs, attending events, using facilities like the Makerspace, participating in research institutes' activities, exploring South Kensington, and taking advantage of support services. These opportunities help you enjoy your time at Imperial, make friends, and build knowledge and skills for the future.

metadata.title: Getting Involved with the Imperial Community
metadata.main_title: Getting Involved with the Imperial Community
key_points: Engage in diverse activities and events
Take advantage of Imperial's facilities and resources
Participate in community activities to enhance your experience

content: This glossary provides definitions for key terms used in university life at Imperial. It includes explanations of academic concepts (like abstracts, bibliographies, and literature reviews), teaching methods (lectures, tutorials, practicals), support systems (Academic Representatives, Personal Tutors), assessment types (essays, lab reports), and important policies (plagiarism). Understanding these terms will help students navigate their academic journey more effectively.

metadata.title: What's what? (glossary)
key_points: Defines key academic and university-specific terms
Covers teaching methods, assessment types, and support systems
Helps students understand important policies and procedures
